timeline.event: TGR-STA-1030 begins initial reconnaissance and exploitation operations, scanning infrastructure across 155 countries
First confirmed breaches of government ministries and critical infrastructure operators detected in retrospective analysis
Group transitions from Cobalt Strike to VShell command-and-control framework to evade improved detection signatures
ShadowGuard eBPF rootkit deployed on compromised Linux servers, providing kernel-level stealth and persistence
Unit 42 (Palo Alto Networks) publishes comprehensive report exposing Shadow Campaigns, revealing 70+ breached organizations across 37 countries

simple_summary.what_happened: Palo Alto Networks Unit 42 research team uncovered one of the largest state-sponsored cyber espionage operations ever documented, dubbed Shadow Campaigns. The operation is conducted by a threat group tracked as TGR-STA-1030 (also linked to UNC6619), believed to be backed by a nation-state in Asia with strong indicators pointing to China. Since January 2024, the group has scanned infrastructure across 155 countries and successfully breached over 70 organizations in 37 countries, including government ministries, law enforcement agencies, critical infrastructure operators, telecommunications providers, and financial institutions. The attackers use an arsenal of custom tools including the Diaoyu loader, the ShadowGuard eBPF rootkit that hides at the Linux kernel level, and multiple command-and-control frameworks including Cobalt Strike and VShell.
simple_summary.who_is_affected: Government agencies and ministries in at least 37 countries worldwide, with particular focus on developing nations in Southeast Asia, Africa, the Middle East, and South America. Critical infrastructure operators including telecommunications companies, energy utilities, and water systems. Financial institutions and central banks. Aerospace and defense contractors. Mining and natural resources companies - especially those in regions with strategic mineral deposits. Any organization running internet-facing SAP NetWeaver, Microsoft Exchange, D-Link routers, or unpatched Windows servers is at heightened risk, as these are the primary initial access vectors used by TGR-STA-1030.
simple_summary.what_attackers_do: Step 1: TGR-STA-1030 conducts massive reconnaissance scanning across 155 countries, identifying internet-facing systems with known vulnerabilities in SAP NetWeaver, Microsoft Exchange, D-Link routers, and Windows servers, building a target database of exploitable infrastructure. Step 2: The attackers gain initial access by exploiting 15+ known vulnerabilities in these products, or through targeted phishing campaigns delivering malicious ZIP archives hosted on Mega.nz file sharing. Step 3: Once inside, the Diaoyu loader deploys multiple tools including Behinder, Neo-reGeorg, and Godzilla web shells for persistent web-based access, while also deploying Cobalt Strike and VShell command-and-control implants for direct system control. Step 4: On critical Linux servers, the group installs ShadowGuard, a sophisticated eBPF (extended Berkeley Packet Filter) rootkit that operates at the kernel level, hiding malicious processes, network connections, and files from all user-space security tools and system administrators. Step 5: The attackers conduct long-term intelligence collection, exfiltrating sensitive government documents, diplomatic communications, critical infrastructure operational data, and strategic economic information back to their handlers through encrypted channels, maintaining persistent access for months to years.
what_you_should_do: Immediately patch all internet-facing SAP NetWeaver, Microsoft Exchange, and D-Link router instances to the latest versions; these are the primary exploitation vectors
Hunt for indicators of compromise including Diaoyu loader, ShadowGuard rootkit, and known TGR-STA-1030 C2 infrastructure on your network
Deploy eBPF-aware monitoring tools on Linux servers to detect ShadowGuard rootkit activity that traditional security tools cannot see
Review and restrict inbound connections from China Mobile IP ranges and other known TGR-STA-1030 infrastructure blocks
Conduct thorough log review of web server access logs for Behinder, Neo-reGeorg, and Godzilla web shell indicators
simple_summary.why_this_is_serious: Shadow Campaigns represents one of the most far-reaching state-sponsored espionage operations ever publicly documented, rivaling the scope of APT campaigns like Salt Typhoon and Volt Typhoon. The scale alone is staggering: 155 countries scanned, 70+ organizations confirmed breached across 37 countries. The ShadowGuard eBPF rootkit is particularly concerning because it operates at the Linux kernel level, making it invisible to virtually all user-space security tools including EDR, antivirus, and system utilities like ps, netstat, and ls. This means compromised organizations may have no idea they are breached even with modern security tooling in place. The targeting of government ministries and critical infrastructure suggests strategic intelligence collection objectives that could affect national security, economic policy, and diplomatic relations for the affected nations. The operation has been running for over a year, meaning the attackers have had extensive time to exfiltrate sensitive data.

tactics.description: Exploits 15+ known vulnerabilities in SAP NetWeaver, Microsoft Exchange, D-Link routers, and Windows servers to gain initial foothold in target networks
Delivers malicious ZIP archives hosted on Mega.nz through targeted phishing emails to gain access where direct exploitation is not possible

tactics.technique_name: Command and Scripting Interpreter: Unix Shell
tactics.description: Executes commands through deployed web shells (Behinder, Godzilla, Neo-reGeorg) and C2 implants on compromised Linux and Windows systems
Deploys Behinder, Neo-reGeorg, and Godzilla web shells on compromised web servers for persistent remote access through legitimate web traffic
Deploys ShadowGuard eBPF rootkit on Linux servers that hooks kernel functions to hide malicious processes, files, and network connections from all user-space monitoring tools
Uses Cobalt Strike, VShell, Havoc, SparkRat, and Sliver C2 frameworks over HTTPS for encrypted command-and-control communications that blend with legitimate web traffic
Collects sensitive government documents, diplomatic communications, infrastructure operational data, and strategic intelligence from compromised systems
Exfiltrates collected intelligence through encrypted C2 channels, with data staged and compressed before exfiltration to minimize detection

detection_guidance.summary: Detection requires a multi-layered approach combining vulnerability scanning for initial access vectors, web shell detection, eBPF-level monitoring for the ShadowGuard rootkit, and network traffic analysis for C2 communications. Traditional endpoint detection tools may not detect the eBPF rootkit, requiring specialized kernel-level monitoring.

log_sources.description: Monitor for indicators of Behinder, Neo-reGeorg, and Godzilla web shell access patterns including unusual POST requests to JSP/ASPX/PHP files and encoded command payloads
Enable eBPF program auditing (bpftool) to detect unauthorized eBPF programs loaded into the kernel that may indicate ShadowGuard rootkit installation
Monitor for connections to known TGR-STA-1030 C2 infrastructure, unusual outbound HTTPS traffic patterns, and DNS queries to suspicious domains used for C2
Scan all internet-facing infrastructure for unpatched SAP NetWeaver, Microsoft Exchange, D-Link, and Windows vulnerabilities exploited by TGR-STA-1030
Monitor for Cobalt Strike, VShell, Havoc, SparkRat, and Sliver beacon behaviors including sleep patterns, named pipes, and process injection

what_to_look_for.indicator: ShadowGuard eBPF rootkit loaded in kernel
what_to_look_for.description: Unauthorized eBPF programs attached to kernel tracepoints or kprobes that intercept system calls to hide processes, files, and network connections
HTTP POST requests with AES-encrypted payloads to unexpected JSP, ASPX, or PHP files, typically with fixed content-length patterns
what_to_look_for.log_field: http_method='POST' AND uri_extension IN ('.jsp', '.aspx', '.php') AND response_code=200 AND content_type='application/octet-stream'

what_to_look_for.indicator: Cobalt Strike or VShell beacon activity
what_to_look_for.description: Periodic HTTPS callbacks with consistent timing intervals (jitter), typically to cloud-hosted infrastructure or compromised legitimate domains
what_to_look_for.log_field: outbound_https=true AND interval_consistency > 0.8 AND dst NOT IN (known_services)

what_to_look_for.indicator: Exploitation of known initial access vulnerabilities
what_to_look_for.description: Attempts to exploit SAP NetWeaver, Microsoft Exchange ProxyShell/ProxyLogon, or D-Link router vulnerabilities from external IP addresses
Users downloading ZIP archives from mega.nz domains following receipt of targeted phishing emails
what_to_look_for.log_field: url LIKE '%mega.nz%' AND file_extension='.zip' AND referrer='email_client'

immediate_actions.action: Patch all internet-facing systems for known exploited vulnerabilities
immediate_actions.description: Immediately update SAP NetWeaver, Microsoft Exchange, D-Link routers, and Windows Server instances to the latest security patches. TGR-STA-1030 exploits 15+ known vulnerabilities for initial access - closing these gaps is the highest priority.

immediate_actions.action: Hunt for web shells on all web servers
immediate_actions.description: Scan all web servers for indicators of Behinder, Neo-reGeorg, and Godzilla web shells. Check for recently modified or newly created JSP, ASPX, and PHP files. Compare file hashes against known web shell signatures.

immediate_actions.action: Audit eBPF programs on Linux servers
immediate_actions.description: Check all Linux servers for unauthorized eBPF programs that may indicate the ShadowGuard rootkit. Any eBPF program not associated with known legitimate software should be investigated immediately.
immediate_actions.command: bpftool prog list && bpftool map list

immediate_actions.action: Review network traffic for C2 indicators
immediate_actions.description: Analyze network flow data for periodic HTTPS beacons with consistent callback intervals, connections to cloud infrastructure with low reputation scores, and traffic to known Cobalt Strike/VShell C2 profiles.

Inform senior leadership and relevant government agencies about the Shadow Campaigns threat. Organizations in government, critical infrastructure, telecommunications, finance, and mining sectors should consider this a high-priority threat. Engage with national CERT if you suspect compromise.
